awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Flexible Network Inference
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists have been studying many natural systems by viewing them as networks, a term used to describe collections of entities and their interactions. Networks are ubiquitous in many fields, including epidemiology, economics, sociology, genomics and ecology, to name a few. A number of statistical models have emerged over the last two decades to describe network data. One common type of model is the latent space model, where each entity’s behavior is governed by its position in some unobserved (latent) space, and if we knew these positions, we could fully describe the statistical behavior of the network. While these models have been useful in many problems, real systems tend to be more complicated. The goal of this project is to fill this gap between models and reality by developing network analysis methods that still perform well even when the model does not fully match the data.   

The specific aims of this project are to improve our understanding of existing network analysis methods under model misspecification, heterogeneous noise, and incomplete or missing data, and to develop novel network methods that are robust to these sources of error.  We consider both these problems under one unified framework that represents the adjacency matrix of a network as its expectation plus entry-wise noise, which encompasses most popular network models.  Within this framework, the project will examine the effects of model misspecification on downstream inference, both for global inference tasks (e.g., network-level summary statistics) and local inference (e.g., node-level statistics). One core goal of the project is developing bootstrap and resampling algorithms for networks, two extremely useful tools in classical statistics that do not yet have full network analogues. Another core goal is developing more general notions of community membership and node similarity, allowing the extension of robust algorithms to a broader collection of network models. Finally, the methods developed will be extended to the analysis of multiple networks. Taken together, these tools will substantially expand the toolbox of network techniques, while accounting for the realities of noisy and incomplete network data and imperfect network models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: FOCUSED RESEARCH GROUPS IN MATH SCIENCES

por.por_cntn:
Networks are ubiquitous in many fields, from genomics, genetics, ecology, and epidemiology to economics, finance, business, and sociology.  The interdisciplinary field of network science has emerged in recent decades to study, model, and explain complex systems of interacting entities that form networks with heterogeneous node variables. This project develops flexible statistical inference methods in the presence of several common noise sources in network data, such as incomplete observations, heterogeneous noise, and complicated dependency structures. Specifically, we have developed statistical theory and methods for robust global inference and model selection, flexible local network inference, and inference for multiple networks and dynamic network data.  It has resulted in twelve publications, five papers accepted for publication, and six papers under positive reviews, all in top professional journals.  The results include novel theory and methods for inference on node profiles,  the community preferences, and ranking on preference scores in heterogeneous networks, understanding the fundamental limit in finding hidden communities in the network, item ranking based on complex multiple-way comparisons with heterogenous features of items, understanding the approximation and statistical properties of neural networks and their ability in finding hidden low-dimensional structure, learning causality from multiple environment data and structural causal models,  learning latent factors and their dependent adjustments in network modeling, reinforce learning under various environments, among others.  The developed network modeling techniques have also been successfully applied to pricing financial assets with heterogeneous firm characteristics and fundamentals, unearthing financial statement frauds from news coverage analysis, understanding its key drivers, assessing its economic damages, and measuring misinformation in financial markets and understanding its associated drivers and impacts on financial markets in terms of trading volumes and returns.


Last Modified: 08/12/2024
Modified by: Jianqing Fan
por.por_txt_cntn:
Networks are ubiquitous in many fields, from genomics, genetics, ecology, and epidemiology to economics, finance, business, and sociology. The interdisciplinary field of network science has emerged in recent decades to study, model, and explain complex systems of interacting entities that form networks with heterogeneous node variables. This project develops flexible statistical inference methods in the presence of several common noise sources in network data, such as incomplete observations, heterogeneous noise, and complicated dependency structures. Specifically, we have developed statistical theory and methods for robust global inference and model selection, flexible local network inference, and inference for multiple networks and dynamic network data. It has resulted in twelve publications, five papers accepted for publication, and six papers under positive reviews, all in top professional journals. The results include novel theory and methods for inference on node profiles, the community preferences, and ranking on preference scores in heterogeneous networks, understanding the fundamental limit in finding hidden communities in the network, item ranking based on complex multiple-way comparisons with heterogenous features of items, understanding the approximation and statistical properties of neural networks and their ability in finding hidden low-dimensional structure, learning causality from multiple environment data and structural causal models, learning latent factors and their dependent adjustments in network modeling, reinforce learning under various environments, among others. The developed network modeling techniques have also been successfully applied to pricing financial assets with heterogeneous firm characteristics and fundamentals, unearthing financial statement frauds from news coverage analysis, understanding its key drivers, assessing its economic damages, and measuring misinformation in financial markets and understanding its associated drivers and impacts on financial markets in terms of trading volumes and returns.
